subject: Re: [junit] Reg:Help on JUnit with HashTable and other issues
msgSnippet: ... Use DBUnit to set up the data and a separate test database for testing. Do not share your test database with anyone. This is one method you /want/ to test
messageBody:
Nagarajan, Naveen (Cognizant) wrote:

> hi,
>
> I have the following queries.Pls answer them.
>
> A.Pls take a look at the following class :
>
> class XYZ{
> public Hashtable stvalues(){
> //this method hits the database and retrives a set of values
> // lets says a persons name,address,salary and computes some values on
> the salary
> }
> }
> assuming i have imported the required packages.
>
> class TestXYZ extends TestCase{
>
> public void teststvalues(){
> //test code
> }
> }
>
> The only way i can test the method is to create a Hashtable object with
> the expected data and compare it with actual data.
> but the expected values for the hashtable depends(indirectly) upon the
> state of database (the values in the table person).
> Also i need to build a hashtable object with all the values(which could
> run into say some 100 rows.if i am having 100 rows ,i need to check the
> all the 100 rows instead of a sample 2 rows of test data .) in my
> database which is tedious.and while building the object,the test may
> also become invalid because the database state may change in time and
> the fixture may become invalid.

Use DBUnit to set up the data and a separate test database for testing.
Do not share your test database with anyone. This is one method you
/want/ to test against a live database, because you are testing your
ability to read data and map it. Just make sure you have exclusive
access to the database.

If you find yourself wanting to do this in more than (say) three places,
then come back for more advice, because my answer will change.

<snip />


> B.Also i am using Junit to test certain functions of session beans ?
> am using a combination of the InitialContext object
> ,javax.rmi.PortableRemoteObject.narrow method,create() method of my
> interface which extends EJBHome to create an instance of the object
> required and then testing the functions .
> Am not sure whether this an valid approach.

It's a valid approach if it works.

> Is there any other better approach ?

Are you testing your session bean logic? If so, extract it to a separate
class and test it in memory. Make the session bean Too Simple to Break
by having it do nothing but delegate to the session bean logic class.
Use MockEJB to test the session bean.

> C. Can Junit be used to test getter methods which have some DB hits and
> some logic in it ?

JUnit can test anything to which a Java interface is available.

> Is it in conformance with Junit philosophy ?

Is it in conformance with the philosophy of Good Design? Google "Single
Responsibility Principle".
